In the face of changing consumer trends, the food and beverage industry must continue to adapt or risk falling behind. With that in mind, here are five key trends food and beverage retailers should be aware of and ready to embrace.
1. Digital is dead – or so the news from the retail industry would have you believe. While some retailers have succumbed to the all-digital fate of music, book and movie stores, the truth is that digital sales are flourishing in the food and beverage sector. In fact, online sales of food and drink have surpassed sales in many traditional retail categories. The key is to embrace digital channels while also maintaining a strong physical presence.
2. Consumers don’t just want food – they also want experiences. That means retailers must continue to offer more than just food and beverages. They must also think about how they can best deliver an enjoyable and memorable shopping experience to consumers. This may mean investing in staff training, upgrading store facilities or simply listening to customer feedback.
3. Healthy options are hot. While traditional retailers may be wary of the health and wellness trend, food and beverage stores that offer healthy options are seeing positive results. In fact, sales of healthy food have surpassed all other food categories in convenience stores and have continued to grow in grocery stores. Healthiness is no longer just a trend – it’s a lifestyle.
4. Store layout matters. Despite the rise of online shopping, consumers still visit physical stores to purchase food and beverages. And, they have a clear idea of what they want to see in those stores. According to a recent survey, shoppers rated a clean, organized store layout as one of the most important factors in determining whether or not they would purchase something. Retailers that invest in improving their store layouts are likely to see increased sales.
5. Sustainability is hot. More and more consumers are looking for retailers that share their values when it comes to sustainability. Food and beverage retailers that adopt sustainable practices are likely to attract customers and keep them coming back.

In a world where people are constantly on the move and seeking new forms of connection and entertainment, social media has become a constant presence in people’s lives. These platforms offer a way to connect with friends and family, share ideas and creations, and consume news and entertainment. But with so much time spent on social media, how do users know if they are engaging in meaningful ways?
A new Pew Research Center study examines this question by analyzing the social media engagement of a nationally representative sample of adults. The study covers the five most popular social media platforms in the U.S. today: Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube, and TikTok. The findings provide a glimpse into the ways people use these platforms and the nature of the interactions that occur within their digital spaces.
Key findings from the study include:
There is more variance in people’s social media engagement than previously thought. While Facebook and Instagram users generally spend more time on these sites than their counterparts, the amount of individual engagement with each platform varies widely. For example, one-third of Facebook users post at least five times per month, but that share falls to just 10% for Instagram users. And while most TikTok users post at least once per day, that share falls to just 2% for YouTube users. These differences suggest that some platforms are more social than others.

This is a region-based analysis of social media and web usage based on the Pew Research Center’s American Trends Panel. This approach provides the ability to examine trends in social media and web use across a wide range of demographic groups, including age, gender, race and ethnicity, education, income, and employment status. In addition, because the panel is based on a nationally representative sample, these analyses can be done with a high level of confidence regarding the generalizability of the findings to the entire U.S. population.
Regionally, the analysis finds that the Northeast has the highest average time spent on social media and the web among all regions. Some 183 million minutes (or 29 hours) of social media and web use are spent here per person per week, on average. The Midwest follows with an average of 167 minutes (or 25 hours) per week, while the South trails behind at an average of 145 minutes (or 21 hours) per week.
At the same time, the Northeast has the highest percentage of internet users who report spending “many hours” on social media and the web. Football scores followed a bimodal trend, with two distinct peaks in 2015 (90%) and 2021 (100%). In between these two peaks, there was a significant drop in 2020 (to 60%). 

Soccer's scoring trend was irregular with erratic fluctuations ranging from 5% to 17%. This is significantly higher than the other sports categories, marking Soccer as an outlier in the data. 

Tennis experienced a consistent decrease in scores from 80% in 2015 to 65% in 2018, followed by a significant increase to 90% in 2019 and further increasing to 95% in 2020 and 100% in 2021.
